Authors: Anastasia Tatik Hartanti, Gayuh Rahayu, iman - hidayat
Title:
Molecular Phylogenetic Analyses Reveals that Rhizopus
microsporus and Rh. delemar are the Source of Indonesian Tempeh
Inoculant
Journal:
The Journal of Microbiology, Biotechnology and Food
Sciences
Keywords:
phylogenetic, rDNA, Rhizopus, taxonomy, fermented
food
Abstract:
Rhizopus has been recognized as economically important
fungal genus due to their contribution to many aspects in human life,
such as source of supplemental food, enzyme, and biotechnological
industry. However, recent changes in taxonomy and identification of
Rhizopus of which heavily depend on molecular approach, produce
significant problem for mycologists in many developing countries,
including Indonesia. Until now, identification of Rhizopus in Indonesia
mainly based on morphological and DNA finger printing approaches. In
this study, 30 strains of Rhizopus spp. isolated from tempeh from
different regions in Indonesia were analyzed using combination of
morphology, physiology, and molecular phylogenetic analyses. The results
showed that 29 strains belong to Rhizopus microsporus, and one strain
belongs to R. delemar. Many previous publications in Indonesia reported
that inoculum of tempeh was R. oligosporus, thus the current finding is
important contribution in relation to validate the information regarding
identity of Rhizopus species used as inoculum of tempeh in
Indonesia
